raw_text:
Worldcom director ends evidence
 
 The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom has finished giving evidence at the trial of his ex-boss Bernie Ebbers.
 
 Scott Sullivan admitted to jurors he was willing to commit fraud to meet Wall Street earnings projections. Mr Ebbers is on trial for fraud and conspiracy in relation to WorldCom's collapse in 2002. He pleads not guilty. Mr Sullivan has spent two days being cross-examined by lawyers for former Worldcom chief executive Mr Ebbers.
 
 Attorney Reid Weingarten has attempted to portray Mr Sullivan as a liar and on Thursday quizzed him about his decision to commit fraud to meet analysts' profit estimates. "At that point in time," Mr Sullivan said, referring to the first false entries in late 2000, "I knew it was wrong and I knew it was against the law, but I thought we would get through it in the short term." Mr Sullivan, 42, has already pleaded guilty to fraud and will be sentenced following Mr Ebbers' trial, where he is appearing as a prosecution witness. Mr Ebbers, 63, has always insisted that he was unaware of any hidden shortfalls in WorldCom's finances. The former finance officer said Mr Ebbers knew about the improper accounting entries that were made between 2000 and 2002 to conceal soaring expenses and inflate revenue.
 
 Mr Ebbers could face a sentence of 85 years if convicted of all the charges he is facing. WorldCom's problems appear to have begun with the collapse of the dotcom boom which cut its business from internet companies. Prosecutors allege that the company's top executives responded by orchestrating massive fraud over a two-year period. WorldCom emerged from bankruptcy protection in 2004, and is now known as MCI. On Monday, MCI agreed to a buyout by Verizon Communications in a deal valued at $6.75bn.
llama3.2:1b: Scott Sullivan admitted to committing fraud for the US telecom firm WorldCom to meet Wall Street earnings projections. He was willing to deceive analysts about profits and hid improper accounting entries between 2000 and 2002. Sullivan will be sentenced following Bernie Ebbers' trial, where he is appearing as a prosecution witness.
llama3.2:3b: Scott Sullivan admitted he was willing to commit fraud to meet Wall Street earnings projections. He pleaded guilty to fraud earlier and will testify for Bernie Ebbers, who pleads not guilty. Sullivan stated he knew the actions were wrong but thought they would be temporary solutions. Ebbers could face 85 years in prison if convicted.
gemma2:2b: Scott Sullivan, former CFO of WorldCom, testified that he knew his fraudulent accounting entries were wrong but believed they could be concealed temporarily. He has pleaded guilty and will be sentenced after Ebbers' trial, where he is appearing as a prosecution witness.  Ebbers maintains he was unaware of the financial misconduct. Prosecutors allege he orchestrated fraud to inflate earnings during the dotcom boom's collapse, leading to WorldCom's bankruptcy and subsequent MCI acquisition by Verizon.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Worldcom's former chief financial officer, Bernie Ebbers, has pleaded guilty to fraud charges after giving evidence at WorldCom's trial of its former CEO Scott Sullivan. The former finance officer admitted he was willing to commit fraud to meet analysts' profit estimates and said he knew it was against the law but believed they would work through in the short term. Ebbs has already been convicted of fraud, but prosecutors are considering a 85-year sentence for all charges. MCI's collapse is seen as an unintended consequence of the dot-com boom which cut WorldCom's business from internet companies.
qwen2.5:1.5b: WorldCom CFO Scott Sullivan finished testifying against former CEO Bernie Ebbers in the latter's fraud trial for 2002 financial misdeeds. Sullivan admitted he was willing to commit fraud to meet Wall Street earnings projections but later changed his mind, stating it was wrong and illegal. Ebbers is facing up to 85 years in prison if convicted on all charges related to WorldCom's collapse.
qwen2.5:3b: Former WorldCom CFO Scott Sullivan admitted he was willing to commit fraud to meet Wall Street earnings projections. He testified that in late 2000, knowing it was wrong and against the law, he believed they would get through it quickly. Sullivan has already pleaded guilty to fraud and will be sentenced after his trial as a prosecution witness. Bernie Ebbers, WorldCom's former CEO, denies knowledge of improper accounting used to conceal soaring expenses and inflate revenue. If convicted, Ebbers could face 85 years in prison. WorldCom emerged from bankruptcy protection in 2004, now known as MCI, which agreed to be bought out by Verizon Communications for $6.75 billion on Monday.

The summary of the text above should be:

1. The former chief financial officer (CFO) of US telecoms firm WorldCom has finished giving evidence at the trial of his ex-boss Bernie Ebbers.
2. Scott Sullivan admitted to jurors he was willing to commit fraud to meet Wall Street earnings projections. Mr Ebbers is on trial for fraud and conspiracy in relation to WorldCom's collapse in 2002. He pleads not guilty. Mr Sullivan has spent two days being cross-examined by lawyers for former Worldcom chief executive Mr Ebbers.
3. Attorney Reid Weingarten has attempted to portray Mr Sullivan as a liar and on Thursday quizzed him about his decision to commit fraud to meet analysts' profit estimates. "At that point in time," Mr Sullivan said, referring to the first false entries in late 2000, "I knew it was wrong and I knew it was against the law, but I thought we would get through it in the short term." Mr Sullivan, 42, has already pleaded guilty to fraud and will be sentenced following Mr Ebbers' trial. Mr Ebbers, 63, has always insisted that he was unaware of any hidden shortfalls in WorldCom's finances. The former finance officer said Mr Ebbers knew about the improper accounting entries that were made between 2000 and 2002 to conceal soaring expenses and inflate revenue.
4. Mr Ebbers could face a sentence of 85 years if convicted of all the charges he is facing. WorldCom's problems appear to have begun with the collapse of the dotcom boom which cut its business from internet companies. Prosecutors allege that the company's top executives responded by orchestrating massive fraud over a two-year period. WorldCom emerged from bankruptcy protection in 2004, and is now known as MCI. On Monday, MCI agreed to a buyout by Verizon Communications in a deal valued at $6.75bn.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so the user has given me a query where they want me to summarize a provided text concisely while preserving key ideas and details. They also specified that I should only output the summary as plain text without any explanations, formatting, or reasoning process. 

First, I need to read through the entire text carefully to identify the main points. It's about WorldCom, their former chief financial officer Bernhard Ebbers, and a lawyer who is trying to prove him guilty of fraud in relation to their collapse.

I notice that the text describes the trial, the cross-examination process, and the legal arguments involved. There are specific details like dates, names, and some financial statements. I should make sure these key points are included without getting too detailed.

I also see mentions of Wall Street earnings projections, so those are important elements to include. The lawyers' descriptions about Mr. Sullivan's knowledge of fraud and the fact that he'll get a guilty verdict add to the summary's depth.

Since the user wants only the summary in plain text, I need to avoid any explanations or additional information. It's clear what needs to be covered—so I'll structure my summary by listing each main point concisely.

I should ensure that all important names and events are mentioned correctly. For example, MCI is now known as WorldCom later on, so I need to make sure that distinction is accurate in the summary.

Also, it's crucial to note that Wall Street might be watching for any signs of fraud, adding another layer to the context. This detail helps illustrate the nature and impact of Ebbers' case.

Finally, the length should be short but comprehensive, making sure each main point is included without unnecessary fluff. I'll check each sentence to ensure it's a key idea from the original text.
</think>

The former chief financial officer Bernhard Ebbers of US telecoms company WorldCom has finished giving evidence at his ex-boss Bernie Ebbers' trial for fraud and conspiracy related to WorldCom's collapse in 2002. Attorney Reid Weingarten is attempting to portray him as a liar during Thursday cross-examination, describing his decision to commit fraud for short-term profit targets. Ebbers pleaded not guilty but will be sentenced if convicted of all charges. Wall Street may be watching for signs of fraud from Mr. Ebbers. WorldCom was rebranded MCI in 2004 and is now known as such.
tinyllama:1.1b:
Le procureur des États-Unis John Neely Bryan (NJ) a terminé les évidences du procureur d'affaires de WorldCom, David Eberson (DZ), devant la cour des grands débts américaine (CG). Eberson est accusé d'avoir fraudué pour atteindre des projections éclairantes sur les abonnés de télécoms américains à l'encontre de ses dirigeants exécutifs. Il a été interrogé par l'avocat de Eberson pour le premier jour de la procédure d'instruction de la défense de Eberson, David Reid Weinberg (USA).

L'avocat de Eberson, Dana Weissman, a interrompu son adversaire en citant quelques-uns des exemples que Eberson aurait déclarés à l'auditeur pour justifier ses actions. Et Eberson, à son tour, s'est efforcé d'expliquer sa decision de commettre un crime pour atteindre les estimates du marché du traitement téléphonique américain.

Eberson a déjà pense que ses actions étaient légales et qu'il avait reçu l'autorisation de son équipe de direction pour faire des avances à partir d'une forte baisse dans l'analyse. Et l'avocat, Reid Weinberg, a déjà conclu que les comptes n'avaient pas été balayés, mais simplement réajustés pour augmenter le rendement de ses abonnés.

Eberson est proclamé coupable de deux charges importantes: fraude et incitation à la perversion d'une profession de travail dans le but de décevoir une partie du personnel. Il pourra être condamné à 85 ans si convicté pour toutes les accusations qu'il a été soulevées.

Le procureur des États-Unis John Neely Bryan (NJ) a conclu la procédure d'instruction de Eberson devant la cour des grands débts américaine (CG). Il a appelé à la défense de Eberson, David Reid Weinberg (USA), pour expliquer les raisons de sa décision d'enclamer Eberson devant le tribunal.

Et Eberson, à son tour, s'est efforcé d'expliquer sa decision de commettre un crime pour atteindre les estimates du marché du traitement téléphonique américain.

Eberson a déjà pense que ses actions étaient légales et qu'il avait reçu l'autorisation de son équipe de direction pour faire des avances à partir d'une forte baisse dans l'analyse. Et l'avocat, Reid Weinberg, a déjà conclu que les comptes n'avaient pas été balayés, mais simplement réajustés pour augmenter le rendement de ses abonnés.

Eberson est proclamé coupable de deux charges importantes: fraude et incitation à la perversion d'une profession de travail dans le but de décevoir une partie du personnel. Il pourra être condamné à 85 ans si convicté pour toutes les accusations qu'il a été soulevées.

Sullivan also revealed that he spent two days being cross-examined by lawyers for Ebbers, now facing fraud charges.
